For the incitability of the nervous system seems to have been kept by the stimulus of the acrimonious humours, which was not sufficiently powerful to increase properly the action of vascular system—hence the internal parts would be loaded, and the acrid particles have a power of exerting their stimulus proportion to the quantity retained—besides, from the torpid state of the circulation, the acrimony would be greatly increas∣ed by the retention of such materials as should naturally have been thrown out of the habit; and this I am warranted to from what occurred on any eruption appearing on the hot tumefaction of the extremities, or by gentle sweat being promoted; for at that time the patients were more considerably relieved.

CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS. Quick nervous incitbi, united with strong mental prepossession, and persuasion, of the patient's own misery, and fatality of their situation, with tor∣por of the vascular system.

CURE. The indications are, to render the nervous influ∣ence more equable, and take off the vascular torpidity; and these are chiefly accomplished by cordials, aromatics, and sti∣mulating antispasmodics, by promoting a determination of the fluids to the surface.

But, notwithstanding gentle perspiration is not singularly , for this purpose antimonials must not be exhibited, must opiates for alleviating spasmodic affections, for they very often do infinite mischief, by relaxing the stomach, and inc∣ing the torpor of the system—stimulants are better, and more the stimulating antispasmodics; such as volatile alkali, asa∣foetida, musk, given occasionally, and the volatile saline intermediately, joined with cordials, instead of the Polychrest salt, (No. 126.)—(of these see the different formulae, page 231 to 235.)—and I have often found the spirit of vitriolic aether and camphor answer every good purpose we could ex∣pect from opium, without producing its disagreeable consequen∣ces—the warm bath in these cases is beneficial.

Though it is necessary to have the body kept open, strong always does harm—occasionally the aloetic pill, (No. .) with or without the calomel, may be given—and as for , we should rarely, if ever, have recourse to it—if it is thought necessary, cupping is the best mode—perhaps bleeding with leeches may now and then be useful in local complaints of the head, or other parts where severe gives much uneasiness; but, in order to keep off an of blood, I should recommend setons or issues—riding on horseback, and that constantly persevered in, is amongst the most remedies—and bitters, with preparations of iron, or in cases without them, generally must close the cure—the waters are extremely useful—and, when patients have strength to bear the cold bath, that may be had recourse but care must be taken to proportion the coldness of the to the power of the constitution, for baths too cold are injurious—indeed in our medical conduct great nicety in these complicated cases, in which we must , that the remedies recommended in the hysteric and hy∣pochondriac disease must be selected, as the complaint verges to one than the other—upon the whole, I found antispasmodics and stimulants to be the most efficacious auxiliaries; former when hysteric, the latter when hypochondriac symp∣toms were the most predominant; in which last they may be used; for it is astonishing in how large doses stimulants be given without injury, and how very necessary they are produce any good effect.

DIV2.HEAD: § 8. INDIGESTION, CALLED DYSPEPSIA,
DIV2.P: the Greek words dys, difficulter, and pepsis, concoctio, —If we consider what has been said of the stomach, and nature, (39, &c.) it will obviously appear, that it is liable to a variety of complaints, such as inflammation, abscess, ulcer, of the lower orifice of the stomach, and a variety of —indigestion is then said only to be considered as a symp∣tom—indeed, it may always properly be considered in this ; for where there is a defect in any of the digestive (see page 72.) this complaint occurs—and if we consider that has been advanced, when speaking of pains of the stomach, the hysteric, and hypochondriac disease, we may form a tolera∣ble certain opinion of its cause, which generally proceeds from a WEAKNESS AND RELAXATION OF THE STOMACH AND BOW∣ELS, and which cause we must consider in this place.

DESCRIPTION. Under this circumstance, there is a of appetite—nausea—vomiting flatulent distension of the sto∣mach, with eructations either sour, rancid, or some other, a∣greeable to the nature of the imperfectly digested, or indigesti∣ble materials contained in the stomach—cardialgia, or heart∣burn, (352.)—pain also in the stomach, attended, for the part, with a costive habit—this disease will also very often pro∣duce the sick head-ach, as proved by experience. Dr. says, from numerous circumstances it is most clea, this head-ach proceeds from the stomach, not the has been the opinion of those who have been suffered by it.

CAUSES. The remote or inducing are, too frequent over-loading the stomach—living upon leguminous and flatulent —sedentary life—too violent evacuations, particularly of —taking too frequently strong purging medicines; dysentery miscarriages; intermittents; and spasmodic affections of the sto∣mach and bowels. The proximate or immediate have been fled above.

CURE. The indications are, to invigorate the tone of the stomach, and, where wanting, to increase the heat—the of doing which have, in a great measure, been set down when treating of pain of the stomach from indigestion, (352, &c.) the hypochondriac disease, (512 &c.) to which we shall only leave to add, that cold liquids should be drank in preference to those which are warm, without actual warmth is necessary to account of the too great coldness of the stomach, and then, in∣stead of tea and coffee, infusion of rose leaves, sage, , or mint, may be used—and the preference should be given to the cold bath.

If meat cannot be contained on the stomach, as will some∣times be the case, cupping-glasses may be applied abo inches below the stomach, stimulating cataplasms, or applied at the pit of the stomach—generous, rough wine be drank cold.

The mode of living should be carefully attended to, means will prove ineffectual—all oily substances, butter, there∣fore, fat meats, and meat pies, all unfermented farinaceous malt liquors, particularly ale and porter, watery and fruits, and raw vegetables, should be avoided—chewing or any thing which promotes too much the discharge of —frequent inebriation are extremely pernicious, as also of venery, indolence, mental uneasiness, or too close application to intense study or business—for should any excess be commit∣ted in eating, though the food should be of the easily digestible
, of which to the animal class patients should chiefly adhere , moist air, without exercise, is detrimental; but cold air it is beneficial—food should be often taken, and in small ; but if patients will not adhere to this rule, they be confined to one kind for several days; and if vegeta∣ble most be indulged in, those which are the most tender, and in their own juices, are the most proper.

we now consider the effects produced in the habit by this , we shall see that a vast variety of chronic diseases to it their origin, and, therefore, on its very first should be carefully attended to; for, if it is suffered to long, it is very rarely radically cured—and, indeed, I persuaded that a great number of those complaints which children born of healthful parents, in their infantile state, produced from the same source, occasioned too often by the of over-fond mothers, or the ignorance or indolence , all which I think may be prevented by adhering to rules laid down when treating of nursing. With regard their cure, similar modes must be pursued as we have laid in the disease just treated, appropriating the remedies to circumstances of the case, and the delicacy of the frames which we have to deal.

DIV2.HEAD: § 9. RICKETS—RACHITIS.
DIV2.P: English name seems to be a corruption of the word , probably from a supposition that this complaint its origin from some affection of the spine, as the Greek raxis, from whence rachitis is derived, means spine.
physicians agree that it very seldom, or never, attacks the ninth month after birth, and seldom comes on after say six, years.

DESCRIPTION. In the beginning, the proportion of many of the body is irregular—the skin loose, the belly thin, and with wind—the muscular flesh wastes away, but the , wrists, arms, knees, and feet grow large—the bones afford support to the belly, and are often accompanied with dness of the spine, from whence all their bodily actions ode of moving on the ground are weak, which often in weakness, unwillingness, and dislike of motion— children it sluggishly in the arms of their nurses, and heavy—at that time the arteries running up the neck full—the head is large, and nods from one side to the owing to the incapability of the neck sustaining it erect, the flaccidity of that, part their dispositions are acute beyond
their age, but the breast is narrow, and, as it were, compressed from its sides with the sternum acuminated, and the extremities of the ribs knotty.

As the malady increases, a slow fever comes on, with cough, difficulty of breathing, and other symptoms, which, the most part, continue till death closes the scene—but this is not always the case—a number of these symptoms we have instances of continuing for a long series of time, still after∣wards the disease ceases to advance, and health is restored, ex∣cept some distortions of the limbs may remain. We have observed, that the opening at the top of the head, called fontanelle, and the parts where the bones join, named sutures keep longer open, and in a greater degree, than others is an healthful state; and the forehead is apt to protuberate in an uncommon manner—the children get their teeth slower, and much later than usual, and those which appear soon become black, grow loose, and often fall out—the desire food, and the appetite itself, is often quick and good; but there is fre∣quently a looseness, or a strong propensity to it—and sometimes the disposition is acute, we have said, now the faculties of the mind are impaired, and dullness and are prevalent.

These symptoms do not all of them prevail in every patient, but more or less of them according to the degrees of or violence of the disease; in some those which are more mo∣derate, in others those which are more severe, make ap∣pearance.

On opening those who have died of this complaint, in the liver has been preternaturally large, scirrhous, and adher∣ing to the midriff—the mesentery beset with indurated , and obstructed with the sweatbread—in others, the lungs to the pleura, or back, and they either livid, or loaded with ab∣scesses, called vomicae—in some the pericardium, the surrounding the heart, surcharged with serum—but in the brain has been found flaccid, replete in its ventricles a thin watery fluid, and the fluids themselves through the ma∣chine in a dissolved state; the muscular parts preternaturally soft and tender, and the bones capable of being cut with a knife, particularly near the places of their union.

CAUSES. The remote or inducing are, bad nursing—suck∣ling children too long—an acid produced from the milk with which the child is fed for the first nine months, or feeding on unfermented ferinaceous substances, and indulging too much in their use, particularly such aliments as possess too firm a , are too viscid and sour, as bread not well fermented, cheese-cakes,
garden fruits—giving children sour wine—living bad air, or low marshy places—opiates too frequently and freely given—want of proper exercise—the habit weakened by preceding diseases—a diseased nurse—and external violence.

The proximate or immediate, a torpid state of the circulatory system, and general flaccidity or relaxation of the solids preter∣naturally increased, by which the organs of digestion, assimila∣tion, and nutrition, are defective in their power, and bring on a thin state of fluids, and want of that matter in them which the bones called offi.
CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS. A large head, swelling on the sore part—tumefied knees and wrists, depressed , distended belly, the rest of the body wasting away.
CURE. The indications are, to increase the tone of the sto∣mach, improve the digestive powers, and invigorate the sys∣tem.

In the first place, however, some of the symptoms are to be eviated, as the stomach and bowels are apt to be foul, at the time the latter distended with wind; they should be emp∣ by gentle vomits and mild purgatives—small doses of ipe∣cacuanha, or of tartarized antimony, should be given for the first ; and for the other, rhubarb and calomel, or Polychrest ; rhubarb is the most eligible, as it is both bitter and astrin∣, therefore a good stimulant and tonic—the vomit may now then be repeated, as it will, by the shocks it gives to the els and the other viscera, of the belly, assist in taking off, or eventing the obstruction and enlargement that often occur in .

The belly also may be rubbed with stimulant liniments, as liniment, or No. 182. which has been strongly recom∣mended—indeed, any of the joints which are swelled may be with this twice a day—and, perhaps, it will be more effica∣cious if it is applied after friction of the parts with a flannel the fire—scae oil has also for this purpose been much , which is used by the inhabitants of the western parts of in the following manner;—first, the wrists and ankles rubbed well with oil in the evening, this immediately raises febrile affections for several hours; when the fever subsides, the me parts are rubbed again the night following, and repeated as long as the rubbing excites similar effects—when, by rubbing these parts alone, not any febrile affections can be excited, the me process is performed, and continued in the same manner on the knees and elbows—then afterwards down the back bones, and on the sides—and when no fever is raised by this operation, a flannel shirt dipped into the oil is put upon the patient's body,
by which more violent febrile affections are raised than any of the former unctions, and is continued till the cure is completed, which commonly happens in a short time.

The chief tonics employed in these cases are bark and steel—of the former, from the nauseousness of the taste, it is scarce pos∣sible to get down a sufficient quantity to render it effectual—however, it may be applied externally to the wrists, by form∣ing the extract into plaister, or quilting the powder in soft lin∣en, (260.) applied in these modes I have been informed that has proved effectual; but I should prefer its being brought into contact with the coats of the stomach immediately, as on that, it appears to me, depends its greatest efficacy.

Steel, as a preventive, has had its warm advocates, who, in order to be able to distinguish whether a child will become ric∣ketty, point out the following symptoms:—a paleness and swell∣ing of the countenance, and in that part of the cheeks, which should be naturally red, a yellow colour approaching to that of sulphur; in which case, five grains of the filings of iron, and as much rhubarb, with ten grains of sugar, should be given every morning fasting and evening—but should this prove too purga∣tive at first, one dose should only be given every day—after month's continuance, a keen appetite ensues, quick digestion and a copious flow of urine—the fullness of the face, and yellow∣ness of the complexion, by degrees are removed, and natural countenance and firmness of the body gradually restored—and this practice, it is said, has never failed of success in any one in∣stance.

Five grains of ammoniacal iron may be given twice a day a month, or longer, interposing occasionally aperient doses of rhubarb; but, in cases of feverish disposition, bark, with the vi∣triolic acid, is more eligible.

In cases of rickets, prepared kali, (177.) half a dram dissolv∣ed in eight ounces of bark decoction, four ounces taken every day cured a boy of seven years old, who has so much that his inferior extremities had become stiff and immoveable—the body flaccid, he was much worn away by a looseness and constant sweatings, and had five fistulous ulcers all discharging at the same time—in the course of one month from beginning to take the medicines he rose from his bed, and walked with support—the bark was then changed to madder, and in less four months he walked with a crutch, and by that time the were nearly healed—the watery solutions of kali have in ricketty people been successful.

Strong beer, porter, and wine have been recommended; but I should rather think them pernicious, the two former from
their viscidity, and the latter from its proneness to become .

But the remedy most to be depended upon is cold bathing, or in the sea, and is certainly the most powerful preventive. otland it has long been the practice with people of all ranks wash their children from the time of their birth with cold ; and, from the time that they are a month old, the supe∣ class dip them entirely in cold water every morning—and, this practice has been pursued, Dr. CULLEN asserts, that never met with any instance of rickets—among the common people, though they wash their children with cold water, they do so commonly practise immersion; and when amongst these with cases of rickets, he prescribes cold bathing, which is accordingly checked the progress of the disease, and seems sometimes entirely to have cured it.

With respect to diet, strong objections have by some been start∣ milk, and where nurses are apt to give large quantities of a kind, it may certainly be detrimental, because it weaken and relax the stomach, fill it and the bowels with humours, and also the machine with too great a load of wa∣, ill-digested fluids, and hence favour the coming on of the ; but where the milk is of proper consistence, and does appear to disagree, it may be persisted in—chicken or thin broth, beef-tea with rice, or rice with cow's milk, proper∣ , may be occasionally given—and leavened bread is to the unfermented farinaceous substances, of which panada may be made, and now and then mixed with small of aromatic species.
Testaceous powders, crabs eyes, &c. (191.) may be given by themselves, or mixed with the food, as they are tasteless; for of we have accounts of their utility.

Exercise in these cases is essentially necessary; but it should the gentler sort, and in an horizontal position, lest, by upright, some distortion should take place—here cradles may be of use, or mattresses laid upon swings, and judiciously to secure the little infant from falling out, which should fixed in the open air, in some shady place, protected from too powerful force of the sun—nurses should avoid carrying in this disease always in one arm, (126.) nor should they , or toss them up much, for the breast may by these means be greatly injured, by the pressure of the thumb and finger on side the breast bone, from indentation or bending of the ribs inwards.

And with respect to situation, as it has been observed, that people who live in damp moist places, where the air in common
abounds too much with watery particles, are more subject to this disease than those who live in dry airy situations, particu∣larly in Holland, all such should be particularly avoided—and by observing the rules here laid down, we may be almost always successful in preventing, and very often in curing this malady, if at the same time care is taken to preserve cleanliness, which is not the least useful rule in our conduct.

DIV2.HEAD: § 10. HYDROPHOBIA;
DIV2.P: so called from udor, aqua, water, and phobeo, timeo, to fear, or DREAD OF WATER—this is by no means a proper appellation the term of Dr. MEAD is more characteristic, DUSCATAPOTIA, from dys, difficulter, difficulty, and katapino, deglutio, to swal∣low, a DIFFICULTY OF SWALLOWING for it has been observ∣ed, that dogs, wolves, and foxes, in which animals this malady arises spontaneously, have, though they have been mad, water, eat, swam over rivers, and run along the banks—however, as an incredible aversion to all liquids is in general the leading symptom, it has retained the former name—indeed, in men have been bit by dogs or wolves afflicted with this malady, the principal symptom is an aversion not only to water, but and light, and they extremely rarely have any desire of . It has been differently divided by different authors—the best of which appear to be into that which arises from the of a mad animal, called therefore hydrophobia rabida, and which comes on from some undiscoverable or imperceptible stiled spontanea.

DESCRIPTION. It generally first discovers itself by the patient's becoming languid, dull, and restless, and having dreams—suddenly the pains, for the most part, shoot the place where the skin was lacerated, all along up to throat, where it causes a sensation of suffocation, and a ability of swallowing liquids—though there is not always a dread of them attendant, yet there have been instances the noise of falling water could not be borne, it created violent agitation, much less the sight.

These spasmodic affections of the throat, in the course of the disease, gradually diffue themselves over the whole muscular system, similar to what happens in tetanus, (415.)—nor is it uncommon to observe, in strong constitutions, a priapism, e∣ven a lustful appetite, exerting itself with some degree of vio∣lence—should the wound have been healed, it begins to be af∣fected with pain, swells, inflames, and discharges a thin,
fluid—this pain is considered a primary invariable mark of a be∣ginning hydrophobia.

CAUSE of the first species, with which we oftenest meet, is the virus of the mad animal absorbed into the habit affecting immediately the nervous system—which virus may lurk inact∣ion in the constitution for fourteen, twenty-one or forty days, within which time it begins to exert its influence; and it is ob∣served to do that the sooner, in proportion as the bite is nearer to the glands, (24.) of the upper part of the throat and mouth, called salival.
CURE. The indications are, to endeavour to take off the spasmodic symptoms, as in tetanus, (415.) and throw the offend∣ing poison out of the habit.

For which purposes we apply and depend upon large doses of opium given every three or four hours—musk also may be liberally—plaisters of opium applied to the throat, and of tincture of opium and camphor—sponges dipt in not vinegar should be put to the mouth and nostrils, that the may be kept perpetually moistened by its steams,—nor should the use of the warm bath be omitted.

Towards the close of the cure, opium may be advantageously with cinnibar, musk, camphor, and asafoetida—opiate glysters should frequently be thrown into the intestines; in , it should be applied to every place, and by every means, expeditiously as possible, in hopes of allaying the violence of highly increased degree of nervous incitability and muscu∣lar sensation—and, in order to procure an expulsion of the poi∣son out of the habit, mercurial ointment rubbed into the ma∣chine, that a salivation may be raised as soon as possible, this continued for two or three weeks.

OIL has lately been recommended in this complaint, thrown into the habit by means of external frictions all over the body, thrown into the intestines by way of glyster, and given by the mouth, when patients can be prevailed upon to conform to the ode—One case has lately occurred, where there was every reason to conclude that the patient was preserved by this me∣thod—sea and cold bathing, with the pulvis Antilyssus, (101.) have been greatly recommended in this disease, which have pro∣duced insufficient.

Indeed, cold bathing appears to me, if not a dangerous, a doubtful experiment, and depends upon constitutional circum∣stances solely for its utility, if has any; for without perspi∣ration can be increased by its use it certainly bids fair to con∣firm, rather than remove, the malady, by forcing the fluids too much upon the internal parts of the system, in which case,
should the habit not be strong enough to exert an expulsive force more than adequate to the impulsive power, the poison would be more riveted on the nervous system, and humourous and sanguinary congestions be added to the nervous affections—indeed, CELSUS himself seems to have been aware of this, or some other inconvenience, arising from the use of the cold baths for he advises, as soon as the patient comes out, to be plunged into warm oil, and drink of generous wine, evidently to and increase the motion of the fluids towards the external parts—in these cases, therefore, the warm bath and frictions appear to be the most proper auxiliaries to the other remedies.
This disease is sometimes succeeded by inflammatory symp∣toms, in which case we may have recourse to bleeding.

After patients have gone through the proper course of the remedies herein advised, sufficient to remove the cause, the cold or sea bathing, adapted to the powers of the constitutions, with the use of tonics and stimulants, may doubtless have in use, in order to give strength and vigour to the system, necessa∣rily debilitated by evacuants and sedatives.

The second species arises without any contagion being com∣municated, in some fevers—from some preceding diseases—from the accession of an epilepsy—from the bite of an epileptic pa∣tient—by the bite from people in violent fits of rage, ac∣cording to the accounts of different authors—indeed an inferior degree of it will be observable in some hysteric cases, where, from the difficulty of swallowing, patients are extremely, fear∣ful of taking liquids, nay, they cannot sometimes be prevailed upon to make the attempt.
In all which cases musk and opium appear to be the remedies most rational, and productive of the greatest efficacy.

When it arises from the bite of a mad animal, the preven∣tive method laid down, (10.) should be strictly observed, which appears to be the best calculated to obviate the most dangerous and too often fatal effects of this destructive malady—and will CHARACTERISTIC SIGNS of which it may be useful close the account; these are, a very high degree of nervous incitability, or super-sensation, attended with a loathing, or dread of any liquid, from the difficulty of swallowing, a painful spasmodic affection of the throat, for the most occasioned by the bite of a mad animal, and sometimes, though less frequently, from other accidental or inherent causes.
